de.dfki.lt.hfc

Class Calc

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.dfki.lt.hfc.Calc

  • public final class Calc
extends java.lang.Object
    a collection of static methods that deal with sets and binding tables, used by the forward chainer; non-destructive: union(), intersection(), difference() non-destructive: project(), product(), join() destructive: project(), restrict() non-destructive: map()
    Since:
    JDK 1.5

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected static TIntArrayHashingStrategy DEFAULT_HASHING_STRATEGY
      the default hashing and equals strategy for tuples from the output set of the current iteration: take ALL positions of a tuple into account
      private static int INSERTIONSORT_THRESHOLD
      Tuning parameter: list size at or below which insertion sort will be used in preference to mergesort or quicksort.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Calc() 

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      protected static void arraycopy(int[][] src, int srcPos, int[][] dest, int destPos, int length)
      don't know whether this special arraycopy pays off (even though it avoids src and dest to be of type Object, it is not a native method)
      private static int compare(int[] tuple0, int[] tuple1, int[][] columns)
      adaption of the comparator from TupleComparator as a static class method in Calc
      private static int compare0(int[] tuple0, int[] tuple1, int[] col0) 
      private static int compare1(int[] tuple0, int[] tuple1, int[] col1) 
      static java.util.Set<int[]> difference(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2)
      a non-destructive set difference operation (in contrast to removeAll) that better serve our needs when we query the index, perform table joins, etc.; should be read as set1\set2; by default, uses Calc.DEFAULT_HASHING_STRATEGY
      static java.util.Set<int[]> difference(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2, TIntArrayHashingStrategy strategy)
      extends the binary version by a third TIntArrayHashingStrategy argument
      static java.util.Set<int[]> intersection(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2)
      a non-destructive set intersection operation (in contrast to retainAll) that better serve our needs when we query the index, perform table joins, etc.; by default, uses Calc.DEFAULT_HASHING_STRATEGY
      static java.util.Set<int[]> intersection(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2, TIntArrayHashingStrategy strategy)
      extends the binary version by a third TIntArrayHashingStrategy argument
      static BindingTable join(BindingTable tt1, BindingTable tt2) 
      static BindingTable map(BindingTable oldTable, int[] toMap)
      this is code originally allocated in class Query that turns out to be useful in ForwardChainer; given a BindingTable object, the wrapped set served as input to the map() method which constructs a new BindingTable, taking over columns, potentially several times, in case of a variable or duplicating constants otherwise; this is controlled by argument args (an int array), where negative ints refer to variables, and positive ints to constants; example ======= input table has three columns with internal var names in this order: -1, -2, -3 args determines output table with four columns (position 0 and 2 same): [-2, 42, -2, -1] input table: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 output table: 2 42 2 1 5 42 5 4 8 42 8 7
      private static void mergeAssignments(java.util.SortedSet<java.lang.Integer> commonVars, java.util.SortedMap<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.Integer> va1, java.util.SortedMap<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.Integer> va2, java.util.SortedMap<java.lang.Integer,java.lang.Integer> newAssignment, int[] transformer)
      private helper for join()
      private static void mergeSort0(int[][] src, int[][] dest, int low, int high, int off, int[] col0)
      adaption of Sun's mergeSort() for Object[] to int[]
      private static void mergeSort1(int[][] src, int[][] dest, int low, int high, int off, int[] col1)
      adaption of Sun's mergeSort() for Object[] to int[]
      static java.util.Set<int[]> monotonicDifference(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2)
      similar to the binary version of Calc.difference(), but assumes that set2 is always a SUBSET of set1
      static java.util.Set<int[]> monotonicDifference(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2, TIntArrayHashingStrategy strategy)
      similar to the ternary version of Calc.difference(), but assumes that set2 is always a SUBSET of set1
      protected static void msort0(int[][] ia, int[] col0)
      sorts an array ia of int[] (= tuples) according to an order established by compare0()
      protected static void msort1(int[][] ia, int[] col1)
      sorts an array ia of int[] (= tuples) according to an order established by compare1()
      static BindingTable product(BindingTable bt1, BindingTable bt2)
      performs the Cartesian product of the tables stored under tt1 and tt2 and returns a new binding table; assumes that tt1 and tt2 do not have variables in common; otherwise the null value is returned as a sign that tt1 and tt2 are NOT independent;
      static BindingTable project(BindingTable tt, int[] pos)
      DESTRUCTIVELY modifies the table field of the BindingTable object tt
      static java.util.Set<int[]> project(java.util.Set<int[]> table, int[] pos)
      given a table, project() constructs a _new_ table by taking into account only the columns given by pos (positive ints including 0); note that project() does NOT check whether the length of the input tuples is compatible with the largest position given by pos; note further that the length of the 'surviving' elements of the result set does NOT change, i.e., some of the columns simply are no longer of interest!! removes duplicates according to the TIntArrayHashingStrartegy constructed from pos NOTE: the positions array must always be SORTED in ascending order to guarantee compatible hash codes!!!
      protected static void qsort(int[][] ia, TupleComparator tc) 
      private static void quickSort(int[][] table, int low, int high, TupleComparator columnOrder)
      slightly slower than mergeSort(); nevertheless, thanks Bernie!
      static BindingTable restrict(BindingTable bt, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> varvarIneqs, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> varconstIneqs)
      _destructively_ removes tuples from the _existing_ binding table which do not satisfy the inequalities; if the input binding table should _not_ be changed, a shallow copy must be carried out first (both for the wrapper and the table itself); varvarineqs is an even (possibly empty) list of Integer objects, representing variables (int value < 0); varconstineqs is an even (possibly empty) list of Integer objects, alternating between variables (int value < 0) and URIs/XSD atoms (int value > 0); NOTE: restrict() does NOT check whether the variables mentioned in varvarineqs or varconstineqs are legal column headings in the binding table
      static BindingTable restrict(BindingTable bt, java.util.ArrayList<Predicate> predicates)
      removes tuples from the _existing_ binding table which do not satisfy at least one of the predicates
      static java.util.Set<int[]> union(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2)
      a non-destructive set union operation (in contrast to addAll) that better serve our needs when we query the index, perform table joins, etc.; by default, uses Calc.DEFAULT_HASHING_STRATEGY
      static java.util.Set<int[]> union(java.util.Set<int[]> set1, java.util.Set<int[]> set2, TIntArrayHashingStrategy strategy)
      extends the binary version by a third TIntArrayHashingStrategy argument

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

      • DEFAULT_HASHING_STRATEGY

        protected static TIntArrayHashingStrategy DEFAULT_HASHING_STRATEGY
        the default hashing and equals strategy for tuples from the output set of the current iteration: take ALL positions of a tuple into account

      • INSERTIONSORT_THRESHOLD

        private static final int INSERTIONSORT_THRESHOLD
        Tuning parameter: list size at or below which insertion sort will be used in preference to mergesort or quicksort.

      • project

        public static java.util.Set<int[]> project(java.util.Set<int[]> table,
                           int[] pos)
        given a table, project() constructs a _new_ table by taking into account only the columns given by pos (positive ints including 0); note that project() does NOT check whether the length of the input tuples is compatible with the largest position given by pos; note further that the length of the 'surviving' elements of the result set does NOT change, i.e., some of the columns simply are no longer of interest!! removes duplicates according to the TIntArrayHashingStrartegy constructed from pos NOTE: the positions array must always be SORTED in ascending order to guarantee compatible hash codes!!!

      • map

        public static BindingTable map(BindingTable oldTable,
               int[] toMap)
        this is code originally allocated in class Query that turns out to be useful in ForwardChainer; given a BindingTable object, the wrapped set served as input to the map() method which constructs a new BindingTable, taking over columns, potentially several times, in case of a variable or duplicating constants otherwise; this is controlled by argument args (an int array), where negative ints refer to variables, and positive ints to constants; example ======= input table has three columns with internal var names in this order: -1, -2, -3 args determines output table with four columns (position 0 and 2 same): [-2, 42, -2, -1] input table: 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 output table: 2 42 2 1 5 42 5 4 8 42 8 7

        public static BindingTable project(BindingTable tt,
                   int[] pos)
        DESTRUCTIVELY modifies the table field of the BindingTable object tt

      • restrict

        public static BindingTable restrict(BindingTable bt,
                    java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> varvarIneqs,
                    java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> varconstIneqs)
        _destructively_ removes tuples from the _existing_ binding table which do not satisfy the inequalities; if the input binding table should _not_ be changed, a shallow copy must be carried out first (both for the wrapper and the table itself); varvarineqs is an even (possibly empty) list of Integer objects, representing variables (int value < 0); varconstineqs is an even (possibly empty) list of Integer objects, alternating between variables (int value < 0) and URIs/XSD atoms (int value > 0); NOTE: restrict() does NOT check whether the variables mentioned in varvarineqs or varconstineqs are legal column headings in the binding table

      • restrict

        public static BindingTable restrict(BindingTable bt,
                    java.util.ArrayList<Predicate> predicates)
        removes tuples from the _existing_ binding table which do not satisfy at least one of the predicates

      • product

        public static BindingTable product(BindingTable bt1,
                   BindingTable bt2)
        performs the Cartesian product of the tables stored under tt1 and tt2 and returns a new binding table; assumes that tt1 and tt2 do not have variables in common; otherwise the null value is returned as a sign that tt1 and tt2 are NOT independent;
